data.title: Text in Debug Console Inserts Unwanted New Lines
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:
The following code will print every character on a new in the debug console window line even though a "," is added after the print statement
```
    for row in range(0, data.shape[0]):
        for col in range(0, data.shape[1]):
            if data[row,col] == 0: # Empty space
                print " ",
            if data[row,col] == 1: # Obstacle
                print "O",
            if data[row,col] == 2: # El roboto
                print "*",
            if data[row,col] == 3: # Goal
                print "X",
            if data[row,col] == 4: # Trail
                print ".",
            if data[row,col] == 5: # Quick sand
                print "~",
            if data[row,col] == 6: # Stepped in quicksand
                print "@",
        print
    print "--------------------"
```

Also any variables in a print statement get printed on new lines. For example the following code:
```
a = 1
b = 2
print "test", a, b
```
will output `test 1 2` in a terminal window but in the debug console it will print
```
test
1
2
```

data.title: Replacing selected text with )]} fails to delete old text with backwards-dragged selection
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new document, and make its contents:
```
{
word
}
```
2. Select "word" with the mouse by dragging backwards. Alternatively, select "word" with Shift + Left Arrow key. It's important that the selection direction is back-to-front.
3. Type the key }
4. Notice how the old text is not removed.

Same behavior for ) and ].

data.title: Paths from the WSL filesystem (bash) do not open on clicks

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 

Ideally, when clicking on files from WSL bash output, they should open in the editor. This is a basic functionality of IDEs for any language. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run bash as integrated terminal ``"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\sysnative\\bash.exe",``.

2. Run ``make`` on a Makefile-based project that doesn't compile.

3. All compile errors will be printed as ``/mnt/c/Users/...`` which VSCode doesn't seem to understand.

data.title: New keybinding complex commands don't have argument descriptions
data.body:
When you run _generateCommandsDocumentation and look in the DevTools console output to get the complex command documentation (commands that can take arguments) for the [Complex Command](http://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api-commands) topic, there are 5 new commands for keybindings.editor.*

These commands are missing documentation for the arguments they take:

`keybindings.editor.defineKeybinding` - Define Keybinding
`keybindings.editor.removeKeybinding` - Remove Keybinding
`keybindings.editor.resetKeybinding` - Reset Keybinding
`keybindings.editor.searchKeybindings` - Search Keybindings
`keybindings.editor.copyKeybindingEntry` - Copy Keybindings

data.title: shellArgs.windows parsing issue
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 build 14393.953

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add the following lines to the user settngs workspace:
```
{
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\Sysnative\\cmd.exe",
    "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": ["/k echo hi"]
}
```
2. Close and re-open the built-in terminal.

Expected behavior: The built in terminal should open and display:
```
hi

C:\Windows\System32>
```

Actual behavior: The built-in terminal opens and displays:
```
hi"

C:\Windows\System32>
```

There seems to be some issue with parsing the arguments of `terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows`, as it seems to be reading the ending quotation mark of the string as part of the echo command.

This may be related to issue #19758.

data.title: Add an option to enable/disable JSDoc autocomplete
data.body:
Hopefully addresses #23642

This PR introduces a new settings option for TypeScript extension:
```json
"jsDocCompletion.enabled": {
  "type": "boolean",
  "default": true,
  "description": "%jsDocCompletion.enabled%"
}
```
which allows to enable or disable expanding `/**` using `docCommentTemplate` tsserver command. When set to `false` the default SnippetString is used.

![mar-31-2017 12-37-02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1029142/24547188/dd1c5e36-160e-11e7-91fd-db9e3e8dea7a.gif)

1. Open a markdown document in VS Code.

data.title: VSCode is forcing the wrong version of `npm` to be used within git integration, linting pre-commit hooks.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607

VSCode is forcing the wrong version of `npm` to be used within git integration, linting pre-commit hooks.  It uses the default npm installation that is bundled with node (as I understand it), but not the independently installed upgraded version (4.4.4, see image insets)

The VSCode "output" tab for "Git" shows the following in my circumstance, but the linting succeeds in other run environments on this same machine.

```
npm ERR! Windows_NT 10.0.14393
npm ERR! argv "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node.exe" "c:\\Users\\jkleban\\Repos\\App\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "run" "test"
npm ERR! node v6.10.1
npm ERR! npm  v3.10.10
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! App@1.1.0 pretest: `npm run lint`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
```

### Steps to Reproduce:

I have a package.json that uses ghooks configured like so:

```
  "config": {
    "ghooks": {
      "pre-commit": "npm run lint",
      "pre-push": "npm run test"
    }
  },
```

Even though my npm is updated generally, VSCode seems to be forcing the use of the wrong version of npm, though powershell, dev cmd, and cmd all resolve the correct one.  I'm sure this test case can be simplified, but actually I couldn't think of how.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17498172/24527343/ab43231c-156f-11e7-9f6c-b7c23e8136ef.png)

I don't recognize any relevant user or workspace settings for this problem.

data.title: Word Wrap state is lost after switching tabs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win 10 x64 pro

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use `Alt+Z` to enable word wrap for current file
2. Switch to another tab then get back to the file you were editing in (1) above. Word wrap is now disabled.

This issue can be very annoying.

data.title: C++ type highlighting and autocomplete #includes
[css] navigate between headings in css comments

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code version | OS
------------------ | ----
1.14.0  | Win 10 x64 pro (french) 14393

>edit: I encourage users to use the [MarkJump](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=spywhere.mark-jump) extension for the job. It is doing it well.

Hi,

For instance _CSS_ files can be very large. Browsing and finding what you want into it can be **very** tedious as it can be done right now in _Code_. Using symbol search palette doesn't necessarily give what you need. Please help us improving that and speed up the process.

The best way I see to resolve this issue is to organize your code with comment section to be able to quickly jump through ToC items.

In _Sublime Text_ there is an extension named [Table of Comments](https://github.com/kizza/Table-of-comments).

![Image](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/dbb8910ec51af12b0874103c8b61a07628962930/687474703a2f2f696d6775722e636f6d2f754968735138412e676966)

You just need to add a heading line in your comment with a special prefix symbol and it will be considered as a new ToC entry. For each new special heading you add in comments in your file, the ToC summary at the top is updated showing all available entries.

But the best is the ability to show a ToC menu in palette presented as a tree of headings entries.

Please add such a feature and make the ToC tree available in a new code panel like asked in #5605

data.title: Can I extend / merge language gammars?

Is there a way to **extend the default [`csharp.tmLanguage`](https://github.com/dotnet/csharp-tmLanguage)** with some additional rule? With references to existing scopes?

May tag this as `question`, also I posted on [stackoverflow.com](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/43125093/can-i-extend-merge-language-gammars#43125093).

data.title: Activity bar: need dark/light icons
data.body:
So far our activity bar was always using one background. Therefor our icons are also just one set and do not adapt to theming as our other icons are. We should use a light variant and dark variant of activity bar icons depending on the configured theme.

/cc @seanmcbreen

data.title: Keyboard layout changes are not detected on Linux

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (6b9548065ad3e31fca4f0e91cf882505fe8c30cf, 2017-03-30T06:18:34.366Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 3.13.0-108-generic
- Extensions: none
---

Found verifying #1549

Steps to Reproduce on Linux under Parallels with a US keyboard (did not reproduce on Mac):

1. Start with US layout
2. Navigate in code to populate navigation history
3. Navigate back / forward with keyboard shortcut (Ctrl + Alt + Minus, Ctrl + Shift + Minus)
4. Switch to German layout
5. Navigate back / forward now works with both the German location of Minus (expected) and the US location of Minus (unexpected)
6. Reload window
7. Now navigation only works with the German location of Minus (expected)

It seems like the layout switch doesn't clear out the old binding.

data.title: Backspace and arrow keys stop working
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win7 Pro SP1 64 bit on bootcamp partition via VMWare Fusion 8.5.6 (and some previous versions of Fusion)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Do some work

Then the arrow keys and backspace key stop working.
Up and down arrows typically work.
Left almost always does not.
Backspace does not.
Right usually does, but sometimes does not.
Delete usually does, but sometimes does not.
Delete and right arrow key might work/not work together.
Closing and reopening VS Code is the only way I have found to fix the problem.

Sorry I cannot find some more reasonable steps to reproduce this.

Thank you!

data.title: Pr 1
Brazilian Keyboard Layout: Can not connect different commands on Windows.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0 - Insideres (bc9a7bb 2017-03-30T08: 11: 58.005Z)
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

@alexandrudima As you suggested in the #22626 

Steps to Reproduce:

1- Edit keybindings.json
2- Click Define Keybinding (Ctrl + K Ctrl + K)
3- Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>;</kbd> on a Brazilian Keyboard

Expected:

Keys showed should be <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>;</kbd>

Result:
Keys showed is <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>/</kbd>


Here a gif with the keys that are different in Brazilian keyboard.

![keybr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/24516152/153b7cd0-1550-11e7-86e2-8af183861fe7.gif)

Here is an example of a Brazilian keyboard. (The settings of the keyboards may vary depending on the notebook manufacturer or keyboard manufacturer).

Example of the keyboard I use.

![teclado](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/24516172/21461f3a-1550-11e7-96de-f6fd5908a595.PNG)

Image of Wikipedia, where it shows that some keys can change position. Example: / in blue.


![kb_portuguese_brazil](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/24588169/785392bc-1799-11e7-95e5-ef488592db2b.png)

data.title: Feature Request: Remove the persistent notification of "show extension recommendation"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1 and above
- OS Version: all

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Fresh install of Code
2. Wait to be annoyed by the notification

The notification persists indefinitely unless we close it, it should be there for say five minutes and it should go away if we don't choose to interact with it. It is annoying. Plus, when I take trainings these days, I use Visual studio code, and when I look at the machines of the students, their file name bar is covered with this notification and they have no clue what that even means, most of them have not seen VSCode in their life (they have seen others of course).

Please put a timer on it.
